verses.text: On the third new moon after the Israelites came out of the land of Egypt, they arrived at the wilderness of Sinai.
verses.comment: This verse marks a key moment in Israel's journey toward covenant. The mention of the 'third new moon' emphasizes the ordered timing of God's plan.

verses.text: After they set out from Rephidim and entered the wilderness of Sinai, Israel camped there in front of the mountain.
verses.comment: The location before the mountain is significant; it fulfills God's promise in Exod. 3:12 that Moses would bring the people to worship here. There is typology here prefiguring later themes of sacred mountains.

verses.text: Moses went up to God, and the LORD called to him from the mountain, saying, 'This is what you must say to the house of Jacob and declare to the children of Israel:'
verses.comment: God initiates the dialogue, reinforcing Moses' role as a mediator and establishing the people as a distinct community.

verses.text: 'You yourselves have seen what I did to Egypt, and how I carried you on eagles’ wings and brought you to myself.'
verses.comment: The 'eagles’ wings' language highlights God's redeeming and protective power. There is a spiritual allusion to being brought to intimate union with God, a theme that will deepen later in scripture.

verses.text: 'Now, if you truly listen to my voice and keep my covenant, you will be my treasured possession out of all peoples, for all the earth is mine.'
verses.comment: This conditional covenant is central, drawing Israel into a special relationship. The idea of a ‘treasured possession’ finds fulfillment in the New Testament as God’s people (see 1 Pet. 2:9).

verses.text: 'And you shall be to me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation. These are the words you shall speak to the children of Israel.'
verses.comment: God intends Israel to have a priestly, mediatorial role among nations. This points toward the New Covenant’s universal priesthood and highlights Israel's mission and calling.

verses.text: So Moses came and called for the elders of the people, and set before them all these words that the LORD had commanded him.
verses.comment: The role of the elders highlights the importance of ordered leadership and the transmission of God's revelation through appointed representatives.

verses.text: All the people answered together, 'Everything the LORD has spoken, we will do.' So Moses brought their words back to the LORD.
verses.comment: The people’s unified response reflects the community's acceptance of the covenant—prefiguring the later role of the faithful in responding collectively to God's initiatives.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, 'Look, I am coming to you in a thick cloud, so that the people may hear when I speak with you, and may trust you forever.' Then Moses reported the people’s words to the LORD.
verses.comment: God’s appearance in the cloud sets the stage for theophany—a revelation combining mystery and intimacy. Also, affirms Moses' unique mediatory role, an early type for later mediation in salvation history.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, 'Go to the people and consecrate them today and tomorrow, and let them wash their garments.'
verses.comment: The call to consecration and ritual purity signals the importance of preparation for encountering God. The washing of garments hints at themes of cleansing and sanctification seen throughout Scripture.

verses.text: 'Be ready for the third day, because on the third day the LORD will come down upon Mount Sinai in the sight of all the people.'
verses.comment: The reference to the 'third day' foreshadows important future events in salvation history, including Christ's resurrection, indicating deep continuity in God's redemptive timing.

verses.text: 'Set limits for the people all around, saying, “Take care not to go up on the mountain or touch its edge. Whoever touches the mountain shall surely be put to death.”'
verses.comment: God sets boundaries to protect people from His holiness. This separation prefigures later ritual and sacramental boundaries and sacred space.

verses.text: 'No hand shall touch him, but he shall be stoned or shot with arrows; whether animal or man, he shall not live. When the trumpet sounds a long blast, they shall come up to the mountain.'
verses.comment: The strict penalty communicates the seriousness of God's holiness. The trumpet introduces liturgical elements, and the invitation after the blast anticipates public worship.

verses.text: So Moses went down from the mountain to the people and consecrated them, and they washed their garments.
verses.comment: Moses performs a consecrating act, further establishing him as a mediator for God's holiness—a pattern for later rites of initiation and sanctification.

verses.text: He said to the people, 'Be ready for the third day; do not go near a woman.'
verses.comment: The call to sexual abstinence before encountering God reflects deep reverence for God's presence and preparation for sacred encounters.

verses.text: On the third day, when morning came, there were thunder and lightning, and a thick cloud on the mountain, and a very loud trumpet blast; all the people in the camp trembled.
verses.comment: The dramatic phenomena express God's glory and power. The trumpet prefigures liturgical worship, while the people’s fear underscores reverence before divine majesty.

verses.text: Moses led the people out of the camp to meet God, and they stood at the foot of the mountain.
verses.comment: Moses leads the people in an act of corporate worship, fulfilling the earlier promise (Exod. 3:12). The collective encounter points toward the communal nature of worship.

verses.text: Mount Sinai was covered with smoke because the LORD had descended on it in fire. Its smoke went up like the smoke of a furnace, and the whole mountain trembled violently.
verses.comment: Fire and trembling articulate God's holiness and presence—evoking awe. Fire imagery recurs throughout Scripture, including Pentecost.

verses.text: As the trumpet grew louder and louder, Moses spoke, and God answered him in thunder.
verses.comment: The interaction between Moses and God, mediated through loud signs, emphasizes mediation and worship with sound—seen later in liturgical practices.

verses.text: The LORD came down upon Mount Sinai, to the top of the mountain, and the LORD called Moses to the top of the mountain, so Moses went up.
verses.comment: God’s descent and Moses' ascent reinforce God’s initiative and the mediator’s role. The vertical movement in the narrative foreshadows deeper spiritual ascent to communion with God.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, 'Go down and warn the people not to break through to the LORD to gaze, or many of them will die.'
verses.comment: The need for reverence is again emphasized, showing respect for mystery and the separation between God’s holiness and humanity.

verses.text: 'Also, let the priests who come near to the LORD consecrate themselves, or the LORD will break out against them.'
verses.comment: Priests are singled out for special consecration, paralleling later themes of sacred ministry, showing ordered liturgical structure rooted in divine command.

verses.text: Moses said to the LORD, 'The people cannot come up Mount Sinai, because you yourself warned us, “Set limits around the mountain and consecrate it.”'
verses.comment: Moses affirms strict obedience to God’s instructions, which reveals the necessity of properly ordered worship and boundaries.

verses.text: The LORD said to him, 'Go down and bring Aaron up with you. But do not let the priests and the people break through to come up to the LORD, or he will break out against them.'
verses.comment: Aaron’s special call sets him apart for leadership, with a clear distinction between hierarchical roles. This carries over into the ordered structure of God's people in later biblical history.

verses.text: So Moses went down to the people and spoke to them.
verses.comment: The cycle of ascent and descent, mediation and instruction, sets the pattern for spiritual leadership and the transmission of God’s word to the community, a foundational principle evident throughout salvation history.
